p: There are increased hospitalizations of older adults on extreme heat days relating to respiratory conditions, circulatory, cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, and all-cause admissions [ 3, 85, 98]. Limaye et al. [ 73] calculated an excess 11,562 deaths in persons over 65 years old following extreme heat episodes during the summer in the Eastern United States. This equates to 20.20 excess deaths per 100,000 persons for older adults compared to 2.40–3.23 per 100,000 for the general population [ 73]. Emergency department visits due to heat were most frequently work related for young adults (ages 25–29) and non-work related for 16–34-year-old Florida residents during warm months (May–October) [ 21].
